title: Assignment 1 - Comparing Modeling Approaches
text:
The journal article “To Explain or to Predict?” by Galit Shmueli clarifies the distinction between explanatory modeling and predictive modeling, emphasizing their different goals and implications.



Explanatory modeling aims to understand causal relationships.

Predictive modeling focuses on forecasting future observations.

High explanatory power ≠ High predictive power.

Researchers should clearly define their modeling objective before choosing an approach.

title: Assignment 1 - Comparing Modeling Approaches
text:
The journal article “To Explain or to Predict?” by Galit Shmueli clarifies the distinction between explanatory modeling and predictive modeling, emphasizing their different goals and implications.



Explanatory modeling aims to understand causal relationships.

Predictive modeling focuses on forecasting future observations.

High explanatory power ≠ High predictive power.

Researchers should clearly define their modeling objective before choosing an approach.

title: Assignment 1 - Comparing Modeling Approaches
section: 2 Statistical Modeling: The Two Cultures - Leo Breiman
text:
2 Statistical Modeling: The Two Cultures - Leo Breiman
The article “Statistical Modeling: The Two Cultures” by Leo Breiman critiques the over-reliance on data modeling within traditional statistics and argues for greater use of algorithmic modeling (e.g., machine learning).

2.1 Key Points:

Data modeling (parametric models, like regression) dominates traditional statistics.

Algorithmic modeling (machine learning, decision trees, random forests) is often better for prediction.

With the rise of large datasets, statisticians should broaden their methods.

Breiman calls for a more flexible and diverse statistical toolbox.

title: Assignment 1 - Comparing Modeling Approaches
text:
3 Comparison & Conclusion
Both papers highlight the importance of choosing the right modeling approach based on research goals.








Feature
Shmueli (2010) - Explanation vs. Prediction
Breiman (2001) - Two Cultures




Focus
Differentiating explanatory & predictive modeling
Advocating for algorithmic modeling over parametric methods


Key Argument
Models should align with the research goal
Statistics should embrace machine learning


Impact
Guides researchers in study design & model selection
Pushed for machine learning adoption in statistics




3.1 Final Thoughts

Shmueli (2010) is crucial for researchers to decide between explanation vs. prediction.

Breiman (2001) challenges traditional statistics to embrace algorithmic modeling.

Both papers shape modern discussions in data science and statistical modeling.

title: Assignment 1 - Information Management
text:
2 Question 1: University Systems

2.1 University System (Student Information System)
Purpose: Manages and maintains student information.
Functions:
- Course Registration
- Academic Records
- Personal Information
- Financial Information
Example: UT Dallas uses Oracle PeopleSoft Campus Solutions


2.2 Online Learning Platform (Learning Management System)
Purpose: Facilitates electronic learning and communication.
Functions:
- Courses
- Grades
- Calendar
- Communication
Example: UT Dallas uses Blackboard’s e-learning


2.3 Online Banking System (Financial System)
Purpose: Offers financial management and access to banking systems.
Functions:
- Money Transfer
- Security
- Mobile Banking
- Account Management
Example: Bank of America Online Banking

title: Assignment 1 - Information Management
text:
3 Question 2: Data-Driven Platforms

3.1 Criminology: Crime Data Analysis Platform
Purpose: Analyze and visualize crime data, helping law enforcement agencies identify crime patterns and improve public safety.
Functions:
Data Visualization (heatmaps, trends).
Predictive Analytics (future crime occurrences).
Reporting (crime statistics reports).
Collaboration (data sharing, inter-agency tools).
Simple Interface Design:
- Dashboard: Key crime metrics, maps, trend charts.
- Analysis Tools: Filtering data by crime type, location, and time.
- Reports: Generate and export reports.
- Collaboration: Chat and document sharing.



3.2 Brain Science: Cognitive Training App
Purpose: Provide cognitive training exercises and assessments to track cognitive health.
Functions:
Training Programs (memory, problem-solving).
Progress Tracking (performance feedback).
Assessments (evaluate brain function).
Reminders (daily training sessions).
Simple Interface Design:
- Home Screen: Dashboard with progress charts.
- Training Exercises: Personalized cognitive tasks.
- Assessments: Cognitive evaluations and reports.
- Reminders: Notifications for training sessions.



3.3 Economics: Personal Finance Management App
Purpose: Help individuals manage personal finances, track expenses, and plan future goals.
Functions:
Budgeting (set budgets, track spending).
Financial Goals (saving, debt payoff).
Expense Categorization (spending patterns).
Reports (financial visualizations).
Simple Interface Design:
- Home Screen: Budget status, spending summary.
- Expense Tracker: Add and categorize expenses.
- Financial Goals: Set and monitor savings progress.
- Reports: Charts to visualize financial health.

title: Assignment 1 - Information Management
text:
4 Question 3: Importance of Data Mining
Why is data mining necessary?
✔ Discovering hidden patterns in data.
✔ Predicting future trends.
✔ Improving decision-making.
✔ Enhancing efficiency.
✔ Personalizing user experiences.

title: Assignment 1 - Information Management
text:
5 Question 6: Example Tables (Users, Posts, Comments)
Below are three database tables used in a typical social media system:


Show R Code
# Users table
users_table <- data.frame(
  user_id = 1:5,
  username = c("john_doe", "alice_wonder", "bob_smith", "carol_jones", "eve_wood"),
  email = c("john@example.com", "alice@example.com", "bob@example.com", "carol@example.com", "eve@example.com"),
  created_at = Sys.time() - sample(1:1000, 5),
  updated_at = Sys.time()
)
# Display the table
users_table


  user_id     username             email          created_at
1       1     john_doe  john@example.com 2025-02-06 13:06:18
2       2 alice_wonder alice@example.com 2025-02-06 13:11:50
3       3    bob_smith   bob@example.com 2025-02-06 13:14:24
4       4  carol_jones carol@example.com 2025-02-06 13:17:28
5       5     eve_wood   eve@example.com 2025-02-06 13:16:10
           updated_at
1 2025-02-06 13:17:38
2 2025-02-06 13:17:38
3 2025-02-06 13:17:38
4 2025-02-06 13:17:38
5 2025-02-06 13:17:38




Show R Code
# Posts table
posts_table <- data.frame(
  post_id = 1:5,
  user_id = c(1, 2, 1, 3, 4),
  content = c("First post", "Second post", "Another post", "Interesting post", "Final post"),
  created_at = Sys.time() - sample(1:1000, 5),
  updated_at = Sys.time(),
  likes_count = c(10, 5, 8, 2, 7),
  comments_count = c(2, 1, 4, 0, 3),
  shared_count = c(3, 1, 2, 0, 1)
)
# Display the table
posts_table


  post_id user_id          content          created_at          updated_at
1       1       1       First post 2025-02-06 13:14:35 2025-02-06 13:17:38
2       2       2      Second post 2025-02-06 13:12:21 2025-02-06 13:17:38
3       3       1     Another post 2025-02-06 13:11:23 2025-02-06 13:17:38
4       4       3 Interesting post 2025-02-06 13:03:57 2025-02-06 13:17:38
5       5       4       Final post 2025-02-06 13:10:26 2025-02-06 13:17:38
  likes_count comments_count shared_count
1          10              2            3
2           5              1            1
3           8              4            2
4           2              0            0
5           7              3            1




Show R Code
# Comments table
comments_table <- data.frame(
  comment_id = 1:5,
  post_id = c(1, 1, 2, 3, 4),
  user_id = c(2, 3, 1, 4, 5),
  content = c("Great post!", "Interesting!", "Thanks for sharing!", "Nice!", "I agree!"),
  created_at = Sys.time() - sample(1:1000, 5),
  updated_at = Sys.time(),
  likes_count = c(5, 2, 3, 1, 4)
)
# Display the table
comments_table
